encodingDesc.p: This document is a simplified "true-to-text" XML version of The Spanish Curate based on Pennsylvania State University's annotated copy of the 1647 Beaumont & Fletcher first folio. Major textual elements and attributes have been captured based on how they appear in the folio. Whenever possible, editorial interventions have been minimalized or avoided entirely. This document is meant to serve as a pedagogical tool by which students of Early Modern literature can learn to construct edited XML versions of the play.

projectDesc.p: The Digital Beaumont & Fletcher (1647) is a collaborative editorial project aimed at making many of the rarely edited—and, as a result, rarely taught—plays in the “Beaumont & Fletcher” canon accessible to student readers and freely available online for classroom use. This project was inspired by the distinctive copy of Comedies and Tragedies Written by Francis Beavmont And Iohn Fletcher Gentlemen (1647) held by Penn State University's Eberly Family Special Collections Library. In addition to preserving evidence of ownership dating to as early as 1703, Penn State's copy of this printed play collection also includes three plays with handwritten marginalia, suggesting that the book might have been used to facilitate performance in the late seventeenth century. This project is also motivated by a desire to make the texts and other features of this book more widely known and readable. As a first step, the whole volume has now been fully digitized, thanks to the department of Preservation, Conservation, and Digitization at Penn State Libraries.

handNote.p: This edition of The Spanish Curate contains the marginal notes found in the Penn State Libraries' copy of the 1647 folio. These manuscript notes are particually attentive to the performance of the play, and prepare actors for entrances and emphasize stage directions throughout the text. These manuscript notes have been added to the text without modernization spelling of puncuation.

My modest thing, hast thou yet spoken to him?
Am I past by his chamber I might see him,Moore with a chese bord
But he is so bookish.
And so bashfull, too.
I faith he is, before he will speak, he will starve there.
I pity him a little.
So do I, too.
And if he please to take the air o'th' gardens
Or walk i'th'inward rooms, so he molest not—
He shall not trouble thee: he dare not speak to thee.
[To Egla, offstage.] Bring out the chess board. Come, let's have a game, wife. Enter Egla with chess board[, places it on a table and exits].
I'll try your mastery; you say you are cunning.
As learned as ye are, (sir), I shall beat ye.
[to Amaranta] Here he steals out, put him not out of countenance.
'Prithee look another way: he will be gone else.
[to Leandro] Walk and refresh yourself, I'll be with you presently.
I'll take the air a little.
'Twill be healthfull.

div.stage: Bartolus and Amaranta begin to play Chess.

lg.l: Will ye be there? Then here? I'll spare ye that man.
'Would I were so near, too, and a mate fitting.
What think ye, (sir), to this? Have at your knight now.
'Twas subtly played: your queen lies at my service
[aside to Amaranta] 'Prithee look off, he is ready to pop in again
Look off I say: do'st thou not see how he blushes?
I do not blast blast: embarrass him.moore be ready
But you do and burn, too.
What killing looks she steals.
I have you now close;
Now for a mate.
You are a blessed man that may so have her.Cross-hatched lines.
Oh, that I might play with her—
Who's there? I come, you cannot escape me now, wife.
I come, I come,
Most blessed hand that calls him.
Play quickly, wife.
'Pray ye give leave to think, sir.
An honest neighbour that dwells hard by hard by: close to, (sir),
Would fain speak with your worship about business.
The devil blow him off blow him off: get rid of.
Play.
I will study:
For if you beat me thus, you will still laugh at me—
He knocks again; I cannot stay. Leandro,
'Pray thee come near.
I am well, (sir), here.
Come hither:
Be not afraid but come.
Here's none will bite, (sir).
God forbid, Lady.
'Pray come nearer.
Yes, forsooth forsooth: truly.
'Prithee observe these men: just as they stand here
And see this Lady: do not alter 'em,
And be not partial, pupil.
No indeed, sir.
Let her not move a pawn, I'll come back presently.
Nay, you shall know I am a conqueror.
Have an eye, pupil—
Can ye play at chess, sir?
A little, Lady.
But you cannot tell me
How to avoid this mate and win the game, too.
Has noble eyes. [aside] Ye dare not friend me so far.
I dare do anything that's in man's power, Lady,
To be a friend to such a noble beauty.
[aside] This is no lawyer's language. I pray ye tell me,
Whether may I remove. Ye see, I am set round set round: surrounded;
To avoid my husband.
I shall tell ye happily.
But happily you will not be instructed.
Yes, and I thank ye, too. Shall I move this man?
Those are unseemly: move one can serve ye,
Can honour ye, can love ye.
'Pray ye tell quickly
He will return and then.
I'll tell ye instantly
Move me, and I will move any way to serve ye
Move your heart this way, (Lady).
How?
'Pray ye hear me.
Behold the sport of love, when he is imperious.
Behold the slave of love.
Move my queen this way?bartolus be ready
[aside] Sure, he's some worthy man: then if he hedge hedge: block me
Or here to open him.
Do, but behold me:
If there be pity in you, do but view me,
But view the misery I have undertaken
For you, the poverty.
He will come presently.
Now play your best, sir, though I lose this rook here
Yet I get liberty.
I'll seize your fair hand
And warm it with a hundred, hundred kisses.
The God of love warm your desires but equal
That shall play my game now.
What do you mean, sir?
Why do you stop me?
That ye may intend me.
The time has blest us both: love bid us use it.
I am a gentleman, nobly descended:
Young to invite your love, rich to maintain it.
I bring a whole heart to ye, thus I give it,
And to those burning altars thus I offer,
And thus, divine lips, where perpetual perpetual: eternal spring grows.
Take that, ye are too saucy.
How proud, Lady?
Strike my deserts?
I was to blame.
What wife, there?
Heaven keep my house from thieves.
I am wretched:
Opened, discovered, lost to my wishes.
I shall be whooted at.
What noise was this, (wife)?
Why dost thou smile?
This proud thing will betray me.
Why these lie here? What anger, (dear)?
Why none, sir.
Only a chance your pupil said he played well,
And so indeed he does: he undertook for ye
Because I would not sit so long time idle.
I made my liberty, avoided your mate,
And he again as cunningly endangered me.
Indeed, he put me strangely to it. When presently
Hearing you come, and having broke his ambush, too,
Having the second time brought off my queen fair,
I rose o'th'sudden smilingly to show ye,
My apron caught the chess board and the men:
And there the noise was.
Thou art grown a master,Act
For all this, I shall beat ye.
Or I, lawyer,
For now I love her more. 'Twas a neat answer,
And it hangs by a mighty hope. I thank her
She gave my pate a sound knock that it rings yet.
But you shall have a sounder if I live, lawyer.
My heart aches yet I would not be in that fear—
I am glad ye are a 'gamester, sir. Sometimes
For recreation we two shall fight hard at it—
He will prove too hard for me,
I hope he shall do,
But your chess board is too hard for my head. Line that, good Lady.
I have been atoning atoning: reconciling two most wrangling neigbours
They had no money, therefore I made even.
Come, let's go in and eat. Truly, I am hungry.
I have eaten already. I must entreat your pardon
Do as ye please, we shall expect ye at supper.
He has got a little heart, not it seems handsomely.
You'll get no little head, if I do not look to ye.
If ever I do catch thee again thou vanity—
I was too blame to be so rash, I am sorry.
